natural problem: A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.

Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = ((10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5))"
shows  "margin_area / page_area = 19 / 40"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes page_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = ((10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5))"
shows  "margin_area / page_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a page with dimensions 10 by 12 units, and a margin of 1.5 units from each edge of the page, find the ratio of the area of the margin to the area of the entire page. The final answer is 19/40.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A rectangle has a total area of 10 inches by 12 inches. If a margin of 1.5 inches is drawn around all sides of the rectangle, what fraction of the total area is not covered by the margin? The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area_total area_margin :: real
assumes h0 : "area_total = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "area_margin = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "area_margin / area_total = 19 / 40"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes area_total area_margin :: real
assumes h0 : "area_total = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "area_margin = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "area_margin / area_total = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a rectangle with a total area of 10 by 12 units, find the ratio of the area of the rectangle after a uniform margin of 1.5 units is applied to all sides. The final answer is 19/40.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = ((10 - 1.5 * 2) * (12 - 1.5 * 2))"
shows  "(total_area - margin_area) / total_area = 19 / 40"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = ((10 - 1.5 * 2) * (12 - 1.5 * 2))"
shows  "(total_area - margin_area) / total_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A rectangular page has a total area of 10 inches by 12 inches. If a margin of 1.5 inches is left on all sides of the page, what fraction of the total area is occupied by the margin? The final answer is 19/40.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page_width page_height margin_width :: real
assumes h0 : "page_width = 10"
and h1 : "page_height = 12"
and h2 : "margin_width = 1.5"
and h3 : "0 < margin_width \<and> margin_width < page_width \<and> margin_width < page_height"
shows  "(page_width * page_height - (page_width - 2 * margin_width) * (page_height - 2 * margin_width)) / (page_width * page_height) = 19 / 40"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes page_width page_height margin_width :: real
assumes h0 : "page_width = 10"
and h1 : "page_height = 12"
and h2 : "margin_width = 1.5"
and h3 : "0 < margin_width \<and> margin_width < page_width \<and> margin_width < page_height"
shows  "(page_width * page_height - (page_width - 2 * margin_width) * (page_height - 2 * margin_width)) / (page_width * page_height) = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A page has a width of 10 units and a height of 12 units. If the page has a margin of 1.5 units on all sides, find the ratio of the area of the margin to the total area of the page. The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page_width page_height margin :: real
assumes h0 : "page_width = 10"
and h1 : "page_height = 12"
and h2 : "margin = 1.5"
shows  "(4*margin*(page_width + page_height) + 4*margin^2) / (page_width * page_height) = 19 / 40"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes page_width page_height margin :: real
assumes h0 : "page_width = 10"
and h1 : "page_height = 12"
and h2 : "margin = 1.5"
shows  "(4*margin*(page_width + page_height) + 4*margin^2) / (page_width * page_height) = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a page with width of 10 units and height of 12 units, and a margin of 1.5 units around the page, what is the ratio of the total area covered by the margins to the area of the page? The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a rectangle with a total area of 10 inches by 12 inches, find the ratio of the margin area to the total area, if the margin area is defined by reducing the length and width of the rectangle by 1.5 inches on each side. The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "total_area = 10 * 12"
and h1 : "margin_area = (10 - 2*1.5) * (12 - 2*1.5)"
shows  "margin_area / total_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A rectangular page has total area 10 inches by 12 inches. A picture is placed within the page, leaving a margin of 1.5 inches on all sides. What is the fraction of the total area of the page that is not covered by the picture? The final answer is $19/40$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page_margin page_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_margin = 1.5"
and h1 : "page_area = 10 * 12"
and h2 : "margin_area = (10 - 2 * page_margin) * (12 - 2 * page_margin)"
shows  "margin_area / page_area = 19 / 40"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes page_margin page_area margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_margin = 1.5"
and h1 : "page_area = 10 * 12"
and h2 : "margin_area = (10 - 2 * page_margin) * (12 - 2 * page_margin)"
shows  "margin_area / page_area = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A page has an area of 10 by 12 units and a margin of 1.5 units on all sides. What is the ratio of the area within the margins to the total area of the page? The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page_margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_margin_area = (10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5)"
and h1 : "page_margin_area = 10 * 12 - page_margin_area"
shows  "page_margin_area / (10 * 12) = 19 / 40"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A 10-by-12-inch page has margins of 1.5 inches on all sides. What fraction of the area of the page is taken up by the margins? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{19}{40}
 ### Proof
 A 10-by-12-inch paper will have an area of $10 \cdot 12 = 120$ square inches. If that paper has 1.5 inch margins on all sides, then the portion of the paper that is not covered by margins will be a rectangular section with length $12 - 2(1.5) = 9$ inches and width $10 - 2(1.5) = 7$ inches.
 Thus, $9 \cdot 7 = 63$ square inches of the paper will not be taken up by the margins. Since the paper has a total area of $120$ square in, this means that $120-63=57$ square inches of the page is taken up by margins.
 Thus, margins take up $\dfrac{57}{120}=\boxed{\dfrac{19}{40}}$ of the page.
 *)

theorem
fixes page_margin_area :: real
assumes h0 : "page_margin_area = (10 - 2 * 1.5) * (12 - 2 * 1.5)"
and h1 : "page_margin_area = 10 * 12 - page_margin_area"
shows  "page_margin_area / (10 * 12) = 19 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If the margins of a 10 by 12-inch page are 1.5 inches on all sides, what fraction of the page is covered by the margins? The final answer is $\frac{19}{40}$.
